Shopify is a global commerce company that provides more than 1.7 million merchants with trusted tools to start, grow, market, and manage a business of any size. [...] ## Helping merchants build customer relationships

Providing a stellar customer experience is at the heart of how Shopify helps retailers manage their businesses. Shopify offers merchants a suite of services including online store setup, branding, point of sales systems, and customer engagement tools to simplify the process of running a store.

A reliable email service is an essential tool to build lasting customer relationships. With Shopify’s email platform, merchants can deliver transactional notifications surrounding orders or reach customers with email marketing to showcase their brand and products.

## Challenge [...] TCNA also needed a tool that offered direct access to data so that they could drive decisions quickly based on insights. Previously, if they wanted to focus on a specific set of data to improve customer experience, they’d have to go through a partner, which could take up to four weeks. And, if all the back and forth through those weeks resulted in a version of that data they didn’t want, they’d have to start the process again.

The business wanted a solution that would empower them to run their own reporting. That way, they could have a holistic view into every dimension they wanted in regard to performance.

The 211 program supports communities across the United States, handling calls and providing key information about social services, emergency support, and more.

## The challenges of a national network

In the United States, the 211 network handles more than 11 million calls a year from community members seeking important social services information. The call and text service, run by nonprofits and some government agencies across the country, helps people locate essential needs like housing, financial assistance, food, childcare, transportation, and more—24 hours a day, seven days a week.

## Topics

Now, it's all in one place. Same information architecture. Same documentation structure. Same resource library. You shouldn't have to waste time figuring out where to find what you need—you should be able to focus on building.

## How this helps you moving forward

Most businesses don't start with a fully mapped-out customer engagement strategy. They start with a specific need: send transactional emails, track user behavior, add SMS notifications, verify identities, build an AI assistant.

The problem with separate websites was that it limited discovery. If you came to SendGrid for email, you might not know Twilio had voice APIs, identity verification, or conversational AI tools that could complement your email strategy. [...] Here's what's moving to Twilio.com:

 SendGrid blog → Twilio Blog
 Segment blog → Twilio Blog
 SendGrid resources → Twilio Resource Center
 Segment resources → Twilio Resource Center
 Product pages → Twilio Products
 Documentation → Twilio Docs

Old URLs will redirect automatically, so bookmarks won't break.

### Your products stay exactly the same

This is a website change, not a product change:

 No API modifications — your code keeps working
 Same pricing — nothing changes about how you're billed
 Same login flows — just a new login page design
 Same features — all existing functionality remains

SendGrid and Segment will continue to operate as they always have. We're consolidating how we present information but not how the products work. [...] We're building a platform that helps modern businesses deliver the kind of frictionless, personalized, intelligent customer experiences that actually matter. This is one step in that direction, and we're glad you're along for the ride.

Global Impact Week was a true testament to the power of volunteerism and the lasting impact we can make when we come together as a team. Thank you to every Twilion who participated, and here's to continuing our mission of giving back in meaningful ways throughout the year!

The latest ebooks, industry reports, and webinars [...] The week reminded us of the collective difference we are capable of as Twilions. From images of teams working together at local shelters to special moments of mentoring, the week was a powerful reminder of how small acts of kindness and service can add up to something much greater. It was wonderful to see the deep sense of purpose that resonated across teams, with employees united in their desire to contribute to meaningful causes.

## Looking Ahead [...] Global Impact Week has come to a close, and what a week it was! Over 1,000 Twilions from across the globe volunteered a total of 2,581 hours, making a meaningful difference in local communities in 28 cities and virtually. Whether it was mentoring students, supporting animal shelters, or volunteering with environmental organizations, Twilio employees showed up in full force to create positive change. This week not only reflected Twilio’s commitment to giving back but also showcased the passion and energy of our employees who are dedicated to making the world a better place.

## Let’s set sail together

If you’re building something cool with Twilio, dreaming up a hackathon, have an event coming up, or just want to say hi, drop me a DM. You can find me as @MishManners pretty much everywhere ( GitHub, Twitch, Twitter/X, LinkedIn, YouTube, Discord, Instagram,etc).

Let’s hoist the sails, chart new courses, share, connect, and build something legendary together. ⚓ See you out there on the dev horizon.

It must stand for something deeply meaningful.

### Aidan Viggiano

#### Chief Financial Officer

Aidan Viggiano is Twilio's Chief Financial Officer. As CFO, Aidan oversees the financial planning and analysis, accounting, treasury, real estate, investor relations, corporate development, strategy & operations, internal audit and tax functions. Aidan joined Twilio in 2019 and most recently served as Senior Vice President of Finance. Prior to joining Twilio, Aidan held a variety of finance roles at General Electric. Aidan has over 20 years of experience. She earned her bachelor’s degree from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.

### Christy Lake

#### Chief Administrative Officer [...] Prior to Microsoft, Charlie spent nearly 25 years at Amazon, much of his time spent as a leader of Amazon Web Services, his last role being Sr. Vice President. He grew the AWS business to what it is known for today, the broadest cloud services offering in the world. Before his time at Amazon Charlie was at Oracle for seven years, growing to become Director of Oracle's Professional Services organization responsible for working with some of Oracle's largest customers to deliver data-based solutions involving both partner applications and customer-developed software. Charlie began his career in Boeing as an engineer, during his time there he played a key role in missions such as STS-61B and the Hubble Space Telescope deploy mission, STS-31.

### Donna Dubinsky [...] ### Christy Lake

#### Chief Administrative Officer

Christy is the Chief Administrative Officer at Twilio where she leads the company’s global People and Legal teams. She is responsible for driving the talent development and acquisition strategy and overseeing all global legal matters, including corporate governance, and government affairs. Previously, Christy was Senior Vice President and Chief People Officer at Box, which she joined with 20 years of experience in culture development, talent strategy, and learning and development. Prior to Box, she held human resources leadership positions at Medallia, HP Software and The Home Depot. Christy holds a Bachelor of Arts in Political Science from the University of Connecticut.

Wear the customers’ shoes

  Spend time with your customers to find out who they are and what problems they need you to solve. Make your customer your North Star, build with empathy, and earn trust through every interaction.
 Draw the owl

  When you're building something that doesn't exist, there's rarely an instruction book. We draw the owl by embracing uncertainty when there aren't step-by-step instructions to follow.
 Write it down

  When you approach a problem, write down your goals, your decision criteria, and your plan of action, as well as lessons learned along the way. This will help you think clearly and communicate effectively.

 Organize into small teams [...] Organize into small teams

  We build best when we are clear on our mission, empowered to make decisions, and can move fast. Organize into small teams so you can stay focused.
 Live the spirit of challenge

  Builders love hard problems. Hard problems are the gold of business, and solving them is why we get paid. Seek out and work on the hard problems, even when it gets difficult.
 Learn cheap lessons

  We get better with each iteration of an idea, so set up well-defined experiments that let us learn quickly and determine next steps.

 Trust is the #1 thing we sell

  As owners, we earn trust by knowing our stuff and doing what we say we will do. Our customers trust us to deliver.
 Think long term [...] When solving a problem, it can be tempting to focus on the here and now and make decisions for a quick fix. As owners, we make decisions that create the best long-term outcomes.
 Have a point of view

  When you get the chance to weigh in on a big decision, have a point of view. Put in the effort to understand the issues and be bold and clear in how you communicate your recommendation.
 Disagree and commit

  Disagree and commit when making decisions as a team. Have honest, open, and respectful debate to get to the best decision then be a committed supporter.

###### Behind the builder: Tanise Love, Senior Employee Impact Manager

Woman with blonde hair standing beside a sign for Croke Park meeting room 01004
Woman with blonde hair standing beside a sign for Croke Park meeting room 01004

###### Behind the builder: Kate Molony, Software Engineer [...] ### We are Builders

We love hard problems and won’t accept a “can’t be done” mentality. We create change and solve the most challenging problems by turning bold ideas into action.

Four cheerful coworkers wearing matching shirts, celebrating in a lively office environment.
Four cheerful coworkers wearing matching shirts, celebrating in a lively office environment.

### We are positrons

We ask how we can help. We empower others. We stand up for what’s right. And we do the work that’s good for our customers, company, and the world at large.

Lightbulb with red accents and puzzle pieces, symbolizing creative ideas and problem-solving.
Lightbulb with red accents and puzzle pieces, symbolizing creative ideas and problem-solving.

### We are curious [...] Draw the owl

When you're building something that doesn't exist, there's rarely an instruction book. We draw the owl by embracing uncertainty when there aren't step-by-step instructions to follow.

Write it down

When you approach a problem, write down your goals, your decision criteria, and your plan of action, as well as lessons learned along the way. This will help you think clearly and communicate effectively.

Organize into small teams

We build best when we are clear on our mission, empowered to make decisions, and can move fast. Organize into small teams so you can stay focused.

Live the spirit of challenge

Builders love hard problems. Hard problems are the gold of business, and solving them is why we get paid. Seek out and work on the hard problems, even when it gets difficult.
